Topic.Title: maybe we'll see timberlane again now that Nemesis showed up, usually happens.

Message.Msg: "I gotta admit: Nemesis has been right more than anyone else about the stock performance of AMZN, if not the timeing of profit growth." Not even management internally knows the timing. It is simply a project driven model where timing of that kind matters much less. Projects are run by discrete, not central groups in the company, and they simply wait until markets are ready to respond on their own. Obviously for the sake of structuring roll outs they will have certain estimates or targets such as with the introduction of Kindle. Those estimates could be wrong and you could end up with a shortage of product as did happen in that instance. Implicit in their model is that markets essential develop on their own for the most part. You can do what you can to stimulate demand but only to a point. You can't really control or predict precise timing. For momentum traders this can be very frustrating. For a long-term investor quite the opposite and very rewarding. Timber's whole thesis is based on market crashes and he simply got lucky during those times and wiped out afterwards pretending he understood one iota of Amazon's business. He understands nothing about the business. He won't be back unless their is another crash. And that won't matter to me since I will just add more and see those shares go up as you said 9 fold a few years later since the drop would have nothing to do with Amazon operating performance.

Topic.Title: WAL-MART- COPY AMAZON BUSINESS MODEL

Message.Msg: how can WMT copy AMZN's business model? They are built on Super store fronts where they get most of their sales, not online. In addition, AMZN is valued on it's future potential in cloud computing and e-book creation, publishing, and distribution, video creation and delivery to it's platform, AMZN is getting into being a complete content creator and deliverer using it's platform. That's what has everyone so excited. That's they will be the dominant creator and distributior of future contet at the lowest cost. WMT isn't doing that or even close to doing that. There's a reason AMZN owns imdb ETC.

Topic.Title: WAL-MART- COPY AMAZON BUSINESS MODEL

Message.Msg: Walmart can do both store and e-commerce. If Wal-Mart decides to let third party sellers use there name like Amazon this could be game changer. Wal-Mart already has the distribution centers less delivery charges. Amazon is loosing money on the other services you mentioned KIndle, video creation, cloud computing. Amazon bread and butter is e-commerce site with third party selling. Use Amazons name to sell products. This is where the cash flow is created. The books are being sold low price. The electronics is the big ticket seller. Look at break down of amazons sales on the internet. It is possible that Wal-Mart could still be a threat to Amazon since e-commerce is still in the infancy 5% of all sales. Just my opinion.

Message.Title: when does the top stop spinning
Message.Msg: i love amazon. long term user of their services. bought stock at 60 when kindles first came out and lament selling too early. congrats to all here. having said that i wonder where all the new growth will come from. there are no homes without internet. i suspect most all who are willing to buy over internet are already doing so. best buy and others matching prices which i believe will ultimately hurt them more but in the short term will decrease or slow growth. without large growth, how long will the market tolerate low margins. will margins decrease as they pay the tax, i dont see them adding the tax to my orders. new distribution centers in each state will increase payroll as well. of course new services. others have tried selling groceries over the internet but a hard road with most buying what looks good in person.
